production.title: Production
production.content: There is no data on plastic production in {{country}}.

trade.title: Trade
keyTrends: {{country}}'s plastic economy is structurally import-dependent, reflecting limited domestic petrochemical infrastructure for the production of plastics in primary form.
Exports are growing more slowly than imports, but show relative strength in downstream segments, notably wigs, synthetic textiles, packaging, and selected manufactured plastic goods.
Imports of plastic waste have declined since 2019, with {{country}} becoming a net exporter in 2020, consistent with stronger waste-trade controls, but exports remain volatile.
Asia supplies two-thirds of {{country}}'s imports, while African markets absorb over half of {{country}}'s exports.
Net trade (imports â€“ exports) nearly doubled between 2017 and 2022, highlighting a rapidly expanding domestic market and rising downstream pressures.
trade.summaryLeft:
Plastic Imports

A total of 2,395 million USD worth of plastic was imported to {{country}} between 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, the total imports reached value of 497 million USD, of which:

  • ~ 37% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 21% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 9% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 32% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

The plastic imports included estimated 82 million USD of plastic packaging imports with notoriously short product lifetime.

Plastic exports

A total of 851 million USD worth of plastic was exported from {{country}} in the year(s) 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, exports reached a value of USD 164 million, of which:

  • ~ 5% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 26% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 3% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 65% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 1% was plastic waste.

Plastic exports included estimated 19 million USD of plastic packaging.
trade.summary:
Plastic trade trends

Between years 2017 and 2022, the amount of plastic imported to {{country}} has increased by 55.7%, while the amount of plastic exported from {{country}} has increased by 23.8%.

Imports are dominated by primary and final manufactured goods, while exports are weighted towards intermediate forms and final manufactured goods. {{country}}'s plastic economy appears demand-led, as imports climb steeply through to 2022, while exports rise modestly. Low exports of primary forms also suggest limited upstream capacity.

Concerning waste imports, {{country}} was a net importer until 2019, then became a net exporter in 2020, suggesting the tightening of waste trade regulations.
trade.tradingPartners: Trade flows are geographically concentrated: Asia accounts for around two thirds of all plastic imports, followed by Europe accounting for around a quarter. On the export side, African markets absorb more than half of {{country}}'s shipments, reinforcing {{country}}'s role as a regional processor and distributor.
trade.productCategories: The World Trade Organisation's database can provide more in-depth insights into specific products. {{country}} predominantly imports plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39), dominated by polymers in primary forms (mainly polymers of ethylene and vinyl chloride) and packaging, with a combined value of over USD 120 million. {{country}} exports plastic packaging, household plastics, tubes, pipes, and hose fittings under this category, with a much smaller amount, accounting for over USD 20 million. There is a significant volume of plastic-based textiles, apparel and footwear (HS chapters 54-65) materials and products both entering and leaving {{country}}'s economy. Exports of textiles are mainly driven by wigs, synthetic fibre products, and footwear for the US (64%), EU (18%), the UK (7%) and the rest of West Africa (11%). Top imports include synthetic fibres and packaging bags, as well as worn clothing and other worn articles. {{country}}'s rubber (HS Chapter 40) economy is heavily import-dependent, driven largely by demand for tyres, conveyor belts, and industrial rubber goods, while exports are concentrated in small volumes of finished or semi-finished products.

consumption.title: Consumption
consumption.content:
{{country}}'s estimated plastic consumption based on net trade (import minus export) rose from USD 187 to 333 million between 2017 and 2022. After a dip in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic, consumption rebounded strongly. This rising consumption reflects economic growth and diversification, but also increasing pressure on waste-management systems, which have not expanded and improved at the same pace.

Although {{country}} enacted a single-use plastic ban in 2020, plastic consumption increased by 78%, indicating the law enforcement challenges faced by the country.

wasteManagement.title: Waste Management
keyTrends: {{country}} generates 3.2 million tonnes of solid waste annually, with plastics accounting for 13-19%.
Only 55% of waste is collected nationally; Dakar is higher (95%) but only 1% is managed in controlled facilities (SDG 11.6.1).
<5% of plastic waste is formally recycled; informal actors may double this contribution but remain unsupported.
Open dumping and open burning remain widespread.
wasteManagement.content:
Plastic waste from municipal solid waste

An estimated 3,209 thousand tonnes of municipal solid waste were generated in {{country}} in 2020, with Plastic waste generation estimates ranging between 340-350,000 tonnes per year. A study on global waste management modelling showed 50% of municipal solid waste is collection coverage, with annual plastic emission including both debris and open burning is 214,610 tonnes per year, which is equivalent to 13 kg/person/year.

In 2021, it was reported ~8,000 tonnes of plastics are formally recycled each year (<5%), with recycling demand (~15,000 tonnes) double supply and strong market growth. Informal recovery is significant but inconsistent and unsupported by policy. {{country}} has over 40 plastic processing firms, but only a few use recycled material due to high capital costs. Initiatives such as ProPlast and Recuplast kiosks show potential for scalable recovery systems.

The estimated MSW generation per capita in {{country}} in 2020 was 0.53 kg per person per day.
wasteManagement.contentRight:
Data from selected city case studies provide further insights into waste management in {{country}}. Primary data collection through a waste composition survey undertaken recorded that high collection (95%), but only 1% of waste is treated in controlled facilities, and recycling remains at 4%. It also showed the share of plastic waste within the collected waste was 10% in Dakar in 2022. The same primary data collection estimated that the per capita MSW generation in Dakar was 0.97 kg, much higher than the global estimate.

Plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste

Total MSW generated from non-household sources 570 tonnes per day, calculated using proxy of 40% of total MSW.

environment.title: Plastics in the Environment
keyTrends: Coastal plastic pollution is severe and persistent.
Urban beaches have more than 20 times more plastic debris than remote zones.
Most litter is plastic bags, packaging, textiles, and fishing gear (mirroring consumption and trade patterns).
Buried plastic levels are extremely high, indicating long-term accumulation.
environment.content:
Beach litter

The national average count of beach litter items in {{country}} was 230,851 items per km2 in 2018. A 2020 study found that plastics account for 98% of visible debris, and density is much higher in urban areas than on remote coasts. Below the sand surface, buried debris reaches 49 items/m2, signalling decades of accumulation.

Common plastic items in the environment

The 2020 study found the items below are most common plastic products found in {{country}}ese beaches.

  • Beach users (food and beverage packaging, straws, lollipop sticks).
  • Fisheries (lines, nets, ropes, polystyrene).
  • Land-based waste (medicine packaging, cotton bud sticks).
  • Mixed municipal waste (bags, diapers, toys, lighters).

These patterns closely mirror {{country}}'s import and consumption profile, particularly packaging, textiles, and multi-layer products, highlighting clear links between upstream product flows and downstream leakage.
